headline: Inside Politics
subHeadline: Two Days To Go Until Biden, Trump Face Off CNN; Awaiting Supreme Court's Decision On Major Cases This Week; Surgeon General Declares Firearm Violence A Public Health Crisis. Aired 12:30-1p ET

utterances.speaker: MANU RAJU, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: A monumental moment two days out from the first Biden-Trump debate of the 2024 election.And joining me now, President Biden's campaign co-chair Democratic Congresswoman Veronica Escobar of Texas. She's also a member of both the Congressional Progressive Caucus and the Hispanic Caucus. Congresswoman, thanks for joining me today. REP. VERONICA ESCOBAR (D-TX), BIDEN CAMPAIGN CO-CHAIR: Great to see you.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Really appreciate it. OK, so you think about Thursday. What is your biggest concern when we head into Thursday's debate?

utterances.speaker: ESCOBAR
utterances.sentences: You know, I'm actually really excited. I don't feel feel concern --

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: You have that some -- you must be losing sleep over something.

utterances.speaker: ESCOBAR
utterances.sentences: You know, I do think Donald Trump may be unhinged. We've seen him be just wildly unhinged at his rallies. And I think the American people deserve a solid policy debate because the contrast that the American people are going to see between the two competing visions for America, the President Biden's vision for all of us versus candidate Trump's dark vision for America.I want people to see that, I want people to learn about it. So my hope is that it is focused on policy discussions.

utterances.speaker: ESCOBAR
utterances.sentences: It is I think probably impossible to fact check Donald Trump in real time. This is a person who, as he breathes, he lies, literally. And as a journalist, you know that, Manu. It's impossible to fact check this person.But I do think that it is highly likely that President Biden will be able to break through that craziness because we've seen him do it before. We saw him at the State of the Union address take on hecklers who were unhinged, some of my colleagues, who were screaming from the audience. And the American people saw a president who cares deeply about them. He cares deeply about us.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: But, I mean, are you concerned -- I mean, the State of the Union, yes, that was an unscripted moment, but most of it was on prompter. This is different. This is 90 minutes. This is someone who's 81 years old. Are you worried about his ability to stay on message?Remember those issues given his age and concerns about some of his, you know, but maybe he's slipping. Some people have raised that concern. Do you have any of those concerns?

utterances.speaker: ESCOBAR
utterances.sentences: I don't. I don't. I have seen the President in action. The American people saw the President in action when he did deliver a really fantastic State of the Union address that hit on all of the important points, things that Americans care about and are worried about. And what he is doing to address their concerns, what he's doing to uplift American families.Fight for our freedoms. Make sure that we have a future in this country versus the man who wants to be a dictator and the man whose economic policies have been panned by Moody's analytics, by cap 16 economists, Nobel Prize winning economists have come out to warn the American people that candidate Donald Trump's plans for the economy would create an inflation bomb. That's what I'm excited to see President Biden lay out and draw the contrast.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: But there's some concerns, you know, our colleague Kayla Tausche is reporting about, you know, the Biden layout, a number of his, you know, achievements. We'll talk about, you know, his -- what he considers his major achievements. That really not resonating with voters.Do you have concerns if he simply lays out a laundry list of things that he believes he has achieved in office that that will may not land well, given that a lot of voters are not happy with the job that he's done in office?

utterances.speaker: ESCOBAR
utterances.sentences: You know, I think the President can do both things at the same time. I think it is really important for the American people to remember where we were four years ago, where we couldn't be together, where we had a president, Donald Trump, telling us to inject disinfectant, calling COVID a hoax, historic job losses, a catastrophic economy, and President Biden inherited that mess and has helped rebuild our economy.Yes, there's work to be done, but it is -- and which is why we're asking the American people to let President Biden finish the job through a second term. But I do think it is important to recognize that the President has helped bring manufacturing jobs to America. Reduced the cost of prescription drugs, more to be done. But he can do both.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: But why do you think -- I mean, more voters think that Trump did a better job in office than Biden? Does that concern you?

utterances.speaker: ESCOBAR
utterances.sentences: It does. I do think that people have amnesia. And as I've been talking to communities across the country for the campaign, especially Latino communities, I have reminded them that about what we experienced for four years under Trump, what Trump left the current president, President Biden with, but also what he's promising to do, which will raise their costs.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Why haven't the -- you know, the Biden team keep saying that when it's a contrast, people will start to recognize that, but it is a contrast and people are still, polls still showing Trump ahead.

utterances.speaker: ESCOBAR
utterances.sentences: I hope that changes and we're working to change that.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Is the Biden team failed to deliver on these messages that you're hoping to deliver to voters?

utterances.speaker: ESCOBAR
utterances.sentences: You know, Manu, we've known from the beginning that this was going to be a tough election. The country is really divided. We're seeing that. You know, I see that on a daily basis in Congress. I see that in communities across the country, which is why we are investing and going to people where they are.This is a long game. I mean, obviously, we've only got about four and a half months left until Election Day. This debate, this Thursday is going to be an important component of that. There will be a second debate and there's a lot more campaigning ahead. And I have faith in the American people that they will see that contrast. That they won't want to see tax increases that a Trump economy will bring or catastrophic job losses that have -- a Trump economy will bring.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: You're a member of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, but polls have shown that Biden has been slipping with the Hispanic voters, that he's not as strong as he was before. What do you think explains that?

utterances.speaker: ESCOBAR
utterances.sentences: I am not --

utterances.speaker: ESCOBAR
utterances.sentences: I am not a big believer in polls, Manu. I haven't been since 2016, where we saw --

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: You don't share any of these concerns about standing with Hispanic voters?

utterances.speaker: ESCOBAR
utterances.sentences: Look, I am concerned about making sure that we talk to every voter, and the campaign is committed to making sure that we do that. We are not taking anyone's vote for granted. We're not taking any group or community or state for granted. So we are putting in the hard work talking to people. We know that Trump and the GOP has abandoned Latino voters. You know, they had -- they announced with big fanfare that they were opening up all sorts of community centers. Well, they've quietly shuttered all of them, they've laid off people in Latino communities. We are doing the opposite. We're investing, we're taking the time, we're having those conversations, because we need Latinos in order to win.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: All right, we'll see how that turns out. But before we go, real quickly, Jamaal Bowman tonight, he's in a New York primary race, are you supporting him?

utterances.speaker: ESCOBAR
utterances.sentences: The -- all of the House Democratic leadership, which I'm a member, is supporting Jamaal. Regardless of where people are on either candidate, I think the American people need to be profoundly concerned by the amount of money being sent in from outside of the district to defeat, it's --

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: 25 million or so.

utterances.speaker: ESCOBAR
utterances.sentences: -- enormous. And that's --

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: A lot of -- most expensive house primary industry.

utterances.speaker: ESCOBAR
utterances.sentences: That's not good for democracy, regardless of who you're supporting.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: The High Court divided. This week, the Supreme Court is racing to the finish line to decide a handful of historic cases. Our next chance to hear decisions is tomorrow morning at 10CNN's Joan Biskupic joins me now. So Joan, there are these major cases left. You've also been doing some reporting about the tea leaves that you've been reading. What do you -- what are you learning?

utterances.speaker: JOAN BISKUPIC, CNN SENIOR SUPREME COURT ANALYST
utterances.sentences: OK, well, first of all, they've got 14 cases and likely 12 decisions the way they'll be --

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: And I want you to tell me which day they're going to tell you --

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: And I'm going to tell you exactly what they're going to do and the vote counts, OK?

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: Don't I wish.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Because they're a very transparent institution.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: Oh, completely.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: So we know they'll be in Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday of this week. You know, they're likely, given the magnitude of the cases to be decided to go into Monday next week. But we don't know. And they don't know, Manu, this is the time of year when they're like in the final throes of decision making.They know the bottom line votes, but they have to see will these decisions right and who's splintering off. And that's what we've seen so much of already, even though they can rule like 8 to 1 in a second amendment gun rights case, everybody splinters off, not just on the right, the sixth justice conservative majority, which is super majority, which you know that there are variations of conservatism on this court. But even among the liberals, the three liberals, there's some fracturing including with our newest Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson tends to write separately a lot. So, you know, back in the olden days, there'd be times when a justice would just sign on and think it's June, I'm done, but not this group. They're writing a lot. But let me just remind you of the three biggest --

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: -- because you asked about those. Really will affect Donald Trump's, you know, probably his election campaign and whether he goes to trial over conduct from the 2020 election results that he was protesting. He has claimed immunity in the face of the charges brought by Special Counsel Jack Smith for election subversion. And the court is deciding right now whether he should be shielded and not have to go to trial potentially before the election.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: And you've been writing about Sonia Sotomayor and some of the tea leaves is there as well. She -- today's also her 70th birthday One, what do you think about those tea leaves when it comes to the Dobbs decision? And two, there are calls for her to retire.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: It's not going to happen.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: And that's not going to happen.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: No, it's not going to happen. She's -- frankly, 70 at the Supreme Court is still young.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Kind of like Capitol Hill. BISKUPIC

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: Or the Senate, I should say.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: And we'll see the implications of that. All right --

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: -- Joan Biskupic, watching it all, thanks for coming in.

utterances.speaker: BISKUPIC
utterances.sentences: Right. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: RAJU
utterances.sentences: All right, ahead, a first of its kind advisory from the Surgeon General's office declaring gun violence an urgent public health crisis.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)
